eventName: Going bald to support my Nan
story:
Hi everyone! First of all I’d like to thank you for clicking on the link and supporting me. As bad as last year (2020) was for us all, it got even worse for me and my family in September when we were told the news that no family wants to hear, my Nan was diagnosed with stage 3 breast cancer. 

After many appointments and check ups the doctors discovered that the tumour was very aggressive so they decided to proceed with a mastectomy. Due it being aggressive, they decided that my Nan should undergo intensive chemotherapy. My Nan’s white blood cell count is now very low which means her immune system is struggling to fight off infections. 

As most of us know, the side affects of chemotherapy can be quite intense and unfortunately after my Nan’s first round she started to lose her hair. Most people that know me know that I am a massive family man and it is frustrating and upsetting for me to watch my Nan go through all of this, knowing that I can’t do anything to help. So I feel as though the least I can do is show her that she isn’t going through this alone as I am by her side going through it with her.

 I’m going to shave all my hair off and go bald on Saturday 6th February. The charity I have chosen to raise money for is Macmillan Cancer Support, I know times are hard for people but any donation no matter how small it is will be very much appreciated! 

Thank you all for reading my story

Peace and love

Charlie xxx

story:
Fiona Hunter and Leah Pullen have joined forces to raise money for Macmillan Cancer Support and to help ensure Cancer does not become the forgotten "C" during the Coronavirus pandemic. Macmillan need your help more than ever before to be there for people living with cancer.

We began open water swimming during Summer 2020, in fact we'd only just mastered the front crawl earlier that year! We're both members of Cleethorpes Tri Club and enjoy running, biking and swimming.
 
Together, we aim to complete the English Channel Virtual Challenge which will see us cover 21 miles (34 km) or 36,960 yards for all you swimmers out there! As swimming pools are currently closed due to government restrictions, we will be swimming over the next few months in cold water conditions at our local seaside resort of Cleethorpes. Our swims will be short and tough, dictated by the tides, weather and most importantly safety, but together we aim to share the miles until we reach the magic figure of 21..... 21 miles for 2021!

We appreciate that times are tough at present both emotionally and financially, so if you are able to donate, whatever the amount, it would be greatly appreciated and make a huge difference to those people who are having the biggest fight of their lives.

Let's help support them by supporting Macmillan and make sure cancer does not become the forgotten "C".

We're sure this charity is close to many people's hearts as it is ours.

Stay safe and stay strong!

Much love and thank you.

Fiona and Leah. xx

story:
Story

While we're all still in lockdown and the days are cold and short, it's so important we're still getting out and exercising... not just for our hearts and physical health but for our mental wellbeing too!
 

This Heart Month, our team are committing to walk/jog/run 100km (60 miles) and we'd love to get as many people across the community to join in on the challenge too.
100km might sound a lot, but over a month it works out at roughly 2 miles a day - that's roughly a 20min jog, or a 30 minute walk. 

We're asking everyone who takes part to set a target of £100 and help spread the word. If we get 60 people to join the team, then that's £6,000 raised for the BHF's 60th year to go towards life-saving research. If 2020 taught us anything, it's that research works!

Some companies have decided to sponsor employees taking part £1/km up to £100 - an incredible initiative to encourage employees to stay active and take breaks away from their desks. Be creative, feel free to put your own spin on the challenge and have fun!

eventName: In memory of Ewart Morton Lewis
story:
In loving memory of Ewart Morton Lewis.

I'm running 126.49 kilometres (the equivalent of three marathons)
throughout the month of February to continue Ewart's incredible legacy of charitable fundraising. Every moment I spent with Ewart he inspired me to become the very best person I can be, to help others despite personal strife, and not to let life pass me by.

Ewart dedicated his life to raising money for a long list of charities and was even invited to afternoon tea with the Queen in recognition of his efforts.

Early last year, Ewart suffered internal bleeding, heart failure, a stroke, and coronavirus. He kept on fighting for 10 months but unfortunately passed away in October. As a family we all cared for him at home, where he wanted to be, in his final five months and some of those moments we spent with him will be cherished forever. He was deeply loved by his family, friends, and community and will be dearly missed.

If you'd like to hear more about Ewart's incredible life I have included a video link for his funeral and eulogy below:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9xfc_wIVMuk&feature=youtu.be

I chose the British Heart Foundation as they fund important research into circulatory diseases, especially heart disease and stroke, which affect thousands of families every year.

This time last year I couldn't even contemplate running 5k a week, so ramping it up to above 30k per week is going to be tough! I'm planning on taking part in at least three fundraising events this year, this one's for Ewart.

Please see below for some more information about British Heart Foundation:

We fund over £100 million of research each year into all heart and circulatory diseases and the things that cause them. Heart diseases. Stroke. Vascular Dementia. Diabetes. They’re all connected, and they’re all under our microscope.
Research has given us machines that can restart hearts, the ability to fix arteries in tiny babies, devices to correct heartbeats, the power to give someone a heart they weren’t born with, and so much more.
We’ve helped transform survival rates but heart and circulatory diseases still kill 1 in 4 people in the UK, they cause heartbreak on every street. And our work is urgent and vital as ever.
Our research, is the promise to protect the people we love. Our parents. Our brothers. Our sisters. Our grandparents. Our closest friends.
Research is who we are. The promise of future cures and treatments. The promise to beat heartbreak forever.
People’s donations have got us this far. Every breakthrough we’ve made, funded by people like you. Together, we can beat heartbreak forever.

story:
Starting on Monday 8th February 2021 members from The Band of HM Royal Marines Portsmouth (Royal Band) will be covering 1206 miles in 50 hours, by running, cycling or walking a virtual route. This will be completed over 4 days. The distance covered is the route linking each of the five Royal Marines Bands by road. These are based at HMS Nelson, HMS Collingwood, CTCRM, HMS Raleigh and MOD Caledonia. This will combine with the efforts of the Royal Marines Band Service (RMBS) who have recently launched a project called '50 For Fergie'. 

'50 For Fergie' is a project for members of the RMBS to raise money by completing 50 of 'something'. This has been created in memory of Band Corporal Iain Ferguson who recently passed away.

Any money raised by The Band of HM Royal Marines Portsmouth will be donated to the British Heart Foundation, a charity of particular importance to Iain's family.

You can follow our progress on this page as the challenge takes place. We would be grateful for any amount you can donate to this amazing cause!

story:
Thanks for visiting my page.  Everyone knows how much I love chocolate so I am challenging myself again and giving up chocolate to help others. I decided to do this challenge again this year because of all the amazing support I got last year for this! I raised an outstanding £155 to help others in desperate need! I have close family and friends who suffer heart conditions therefor this is an important charity for me. I'm raising money for the British Heart Foundation's research and I'd be so grateful for your support. The BHF has helped halve the number of people dying from heart and circulatory disease in the UK but sadly every day hundreds of people lose their lives. It's only thanks to support from people like us that the BHF can create new treatments and discover new cures. £24 could pay for two hours of research by an early career scientist, but every pound helps so please give what you can to help me hit my target. 

The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half.Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

Thank you!

story:
To add a bit of clarity to this whole thing - as I sit here writing this, I'm eating a chocolate cornflake bun. So, yeah.

I have a lot of okay memories of the time around Christmas 2010 - trying my first gingerbread latte, hanging out constantly at the Christkindelmarkt in Leeds, wondering what I was going to do for my 21st birthday that was fast approaching, seeing my family and friends come together in the best of ways and having to buy 5 kids Christmas presents for the first time. But they're all slightly tinged with sadness, and I have a lot of not okay memories of that time too.

I was drinking coffee at the Christmas market so much because its location in Millennium Square was a short walk away from the LGI, where my Dad was being treated for ventricular heart failure. He'd already been in Calderdale Royal for a while before that, and our lives had become a routine of go about your day as best you could, then trek up to the hospital for visiting times, grab something quick to eat and then head home to await the phone calls from people wanting to know what was happening. (If you challenged me to, I could probably still find my way to Ward 6C in Halifax with my eyes closed and one hand tied behind my back.)

At the time, the hospital had some leaflets on things we could expect to happen, changes to look out for, and things to ask the doctors about. These were available for free, sitting in a holder on one of the ward's walls thanks to the British Heart Foundation. And those leaflets helped us deal more than we could say. So if I can, I want to help give a bit back.

There are some stories from that time and the months that followed that are on the lighter side too. The ice in the flasks, cheese you could read a newspaper through, a nurse pulling my Mum to the side to warn her about my Dad's appearance (he'd gotten bored and shaved his own head), sitting as a family eating fruit ice lollies in a ward lounge, my Dad forgetting the word "Freemasons", the letter in which it was stated that my Dad was "turning the coroner", and the magazine story, which is one best not told in polite company.

The Covid pandemic has affected a lot of things in our lives, and one of those is the ability for charities to raise money to fund what they do. If I can raise even a bit of money by giving up chocolate for a month, maybe it will help a family who are in the situation we were in, and to me, that makes it all worth it. If you can donate, I'm eternally grateful, and if you can't, the fact that you've made it this far means a lot to me. Thank you.

(As an aside - if I don't hit my target, I'm going to pay any money that's short myself. Because it's a cause that's close to my heart. Pun very much intended.)

story:
HELLO EVERYONE! 

Now it’s no surprise to any of you that I LOVE Kit Kat Chunky’s and partial to the odd box of malteasers to celebrate the kettle being put on. BUT... I’ve just signed up for this. WITHOUT THINKING CLEARLY OBVIOUSLY! 

So for the whole of March I’m committing to not eating any chocolate, sweets or fizzy drinks. 

But genuinely I think this is going to be really hard for me. I even have emergency Haribo hidden in my inside pocket in my work uniform! And I can sniff a tub of celebrations being open 3 offices away! 

It’s unlikely I’m ever going to run a marathon but I promise I won’t eat a Marathon in the whole of March. 

If you’ve got a couple of pounds please support me, if not a ‘like’ on one of my posts will be equally appreciated as I love a bit of support!  Over the last year we’ve all had a tough time. Some more than others. Secretly or publicly these battles are all battles. BHF support so many people and invest so much into research and we need to keep this going through this trying time. If everyone does their bit, we can spread our love (not Nutella) and make us all feel alittle but better. 

To be honest I’m not sure what I’m going to eat for breakfast as 4 Bourbon biscuits set me up for the day! ... might as well turn vegan and be done with it!!! — Just to point out I’m not turning vegan. Life without Bacon and Chocolate would be unbearable. 

ANY HOW!!! Here’s to being miserable all March 😂

I don’t think there is a day that goes by where we don’t have
chocolate in some form….Its our go-to snack, our celebratory food and our stress reliever.

We have wanted to challenge ourselves to do something for some time now and a fitness one is just not our forte. So this was just perfect for us and one that we are going to find extremely tough.

Just after Christmas we suddenly lost a very close friend to
this horrible disease and we wanted to raise critical funds for such important research in his memory. Not only a close friend but like a Dad to Clinton, and chocolate was kind of our thing (You know the Australian Timtam thing where you bite there corners off and drink your tea/coffee through the biscuit…. We always did that 😉)

So we thought we would take part in the British Heart Foundation
Dechox for March as would be the perfect way to push ourselves and raise money in his memory. Despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers and research into cures and preventions is so important so if you could donate just a small amount it goes a long way to help.

Tim… this is for you.

eventName: Peter’s 21 ultramarathons in 21 days challenge from a day chair
story:
Hi everyone and thanks for stopping by. This is the fundraiser page for my 21 ultramarathons in 21 days challenge I’ll be doing from my everyday wheelchair this February for the Guide Dogs For The Blind Association. I’ll be doing a 52.4 mile ultra or the equivalent of 2 marathons back to back every day for 21 days from the 1st February 2021.

A bit about me. My name is Peter Smorthit and I’m a 29 year old T10 complete paraplegic. I was involved in a scaffold collapse accident on a building site I was working on ten years ago age 19 which left me paralysed from just above the waist down and completely reliant on a wheelchair. I also sustained a secondary injury at T4/5 which affects my diaphragm and balance. I’ve survived sepsis and had 2 full on strokes since as well but refuse to let any of that define me and continue to live life to the fullest I can helping out great causes along the way too with my marathons, triathlons and mad challenges I do from my wheelchair like this one. So far to date I’ve completed 132 Marathons, 103 Half Marathons and 79 Ultramarathons from my everyday wheelchair. I’ve  got 21 more Ultramarathons to go to reach my 100th ultra milestone and came up with the idea of doing 52.4 miles or the equivalent of 2 marathons a day back to back for 21 days from my everyday wheelchair. Wanted to do something for another brilliant cause and thought what better than to do this challenge for The Guide Dogs for The Blind Association.

Hoping through doing this challenge I can raise awareness of the important role guide dogs play in keeping so many visually impaired people living independently, enabling them to do the everyday tasks so many of us take for granted and to be able to raise funds to help them continue their brilliant work providing a lifeline to so many visually impaired people through the use of assistance dogs. Any donations no matter how small or shares/ spreading the word are all greatly appreciated. Thanks for reading.

story:
In the UK today, almost two million people are living with sight loss and of those, around 180,000 rarely leave their homes alone. Many suffer from depression and struggle with feelings of isolation.

Guide Dogs is here to help solve this problem. We provide individual support that overcomes the emotional and physical challenges faced by people living with sight loss.

We work for a world where people with sight loss are never left out of life. We work for a world where blind people no longer feel invisible, where the quality of their eye sight is genuinely the only difference between them and the rest of society.

A world with enough support to make the challenges of sight loss no barrier to fulfilling your needs and dreams. A world where being blind or partially sighted isn't what defines you.

story:
Approaching my 60th birthday in March and what should have been Tony’s 60th in August, it feels right to me to raise funds for Cancer Research instead of birthday gifts to help them continue to invest in vital research. There are many people here today who simply would not be alive if it wasn’t for Cancer Research, their trials have literally saved lives. There’s a long way to go but the funding is essential.

Tony’s diagnosis devastatingly came too late and he was not able to have treatment to save him but there’s been so many advances in treatment and I hope to contribute to future trials.

Tony has missed out on far too much dying at the young age of 43 with lung cancer. He never got the chance to meet Thomas's beautiful and wonderful wife Gemma,  and our darling Grandson, Samuel. If any of you are able to donate in recognition of my 60th and should have been Tony’s, it would mean the World to myself, Tom and Nat. I fully appreciate that not everyone will be able to donate during such uncertain times but any donations made in Tony’s memory would be fantastic. Let’s stop other families from going through this utter devastation. He would have been so proud of our children our world..

Marie Curie provides care and support for people living with any terminal illness across the UK. Our nurses work night and day in peoples homes and our hospices offer specialist care. We also support people emotionally, provide practical information, and match them with trained volunteers.

Hello its Emily here👋, as many of you know i am a very keen sportswomen and through lockdown I have been very keen to keep fit and strong🏃‍🏏💪. Please read on to see how i plan to push myself to support Marie Curie🌻 ....

Since my Great Grandad Joe died 8 years ago we have raised money for Marie Curie as a family but over the past 12 months most of our fundraising plans have been cancelled. Marie Curie supported my family when my grandad  was very ill. He was desperate to be in his own home with his family who he loved. Marie Curie helped my Great Grandma Eun and Grandma Tina to make sure  this could happen. They provided nurses to sit with Grandad through some nights, to give the family a rest even though they were only upstairs they had the peace of mind someone was there just to chat with him if he wished and could call grandma down if needed. It also meant I could sit on his bed and eat a Chinese takeaway with him (this was his favourite),  I would stand on his bed and brush his hair and put my clips in it to make him laugh.

People need these wonderful nurses and carers, Marie Curie rely on fundraising to help them continue to help others, these are difficult times but please help me raise much needed funds for Marie Curie so other families can benefit from their support as we did. 🙏🙌


I aim to run 🏃‍60 km through the month of February for this cause, I am definitely up for the challenge!


If you feel able, please support me, every little helps.

Feel free to share my page with your friends and family to help Marie Curie.🌻


Thanks for reading and I will keep you updated!!

story:
Superdrug have launched a 180 Challenge for Marie Curie this February.

Colleagues are completing challenges to do with the numbers 180, 18 or 1.8 with a target to raise £180 to fund a night of Marie Curie care. 

With healthcare services reaching their limit, Marie Curie's care has never been needed more than ever. Superdrug are raising vital funds to ensure their nurses can remain on the frontline, day and night, providing critical end of life care to families in the comfort of their own home. 

With your support, Marie Curie can - and will continue to be - there for families in their hour of need.

Thank you!

We'll be here for you and your family when you may feel like no-one else is, to help you cope when you don't know how. Marie Curie Nurses care for you in your home, when you need them most, day or night. Our hospices are at the heart of communities around the UK. And our trained volunteers and advisers are here for you with practical information and support when you don't know what to do next or just need to talk. 
We'll be by your side with care and support every step of the way, bringing light in the darkest hours.

charity.description: RNLI volunteer lifeboat crews provide a 24-hour search and rescue service all around the UK and Ireland, while lifeguards keep a careful watch on the UK’s busiest beaches. RNLI lifesaving and drowning prevention depend on supporter fundraising and the generous donations that you and others give.
charity.name: RNLI - Royal National Lifeboat Institution
story:
On 1st October my husband Richard Watson (Watty) was killed in a road traffic accident.  The comments in the letters, texts, emails,
messages and cards that I received over the following weeks all told tales of a man that was loved by many and that who had in one way or another enriched people’s lives by helping or supporting them or just by being a friend.  The comments often contained the following remarks: larger than life, lit the room up with his presence, always had time for me, would go out of his way to help, had a loud laugh, a wicked sense of humour and was great at fabulous off the cuff comments.

Watty was well known in the Skegness community – from an early age he played cricket and hockey for Skegness and eventually took on the role of Secretary for Skegness Cricket Club for a number of years.  Golf eventually took over from other sports and he joined Seacroft Golf Club where he would always be found in the bar afterwards discussing the game in great detail with his regular playing partners.

Watty’s main passion was Skegness Lifeboat.  After some time as a shore helper he became a crew member in 1987 and after 32 years of service he finally retired in 2019.  His lifeboat service record shows he started as a shore helper in 1986, became a crew member on the inshore lifeboat in 1987 and was Senior Helmsman of this boat when he finally reached the age limit for the inshore in 2008. 

Watty became a crew member for the All Weather Lifeboat in 1991 and served as navigator, deputy 2nd Coxswain, 2nd Coxswain and eventually held the role of Coxswain from 2017 - 2019.  He also spent time volunteering at Tower Pier on the Thames from 2002-2003 whilst continuing to volunteer at Skegness.  His RNLI service record shows that he “rescued 246 lives from shipwreck”.  Watty was a very humble man with regard to his long service with the RNLI despite his outgoing jovial persona in normal life.

The Skegness Lifeboat Crew spend hours training to maintain the skills needed to be on call 24/7 365 days of the year.  Watty spent several years as the Station Training Officer and as a lasting tribute to him, his family and friends would like to raise monies to help build and kit out a training room at Skegness Lifeboat Station in his memory. As a target we would like to raise up to £50,000 over the next 2-3 years to ensure the monies are available when the station is, in due course, refurbished. This will ensure that the station eventually has a dedicated training area which will be a fitting tribute to the work of a
friendly, outgoing and modest hero.  

We hope, eventually, to be able to organise fundraising events when we are able to return to some sort of normal life post covid but in the interim we have set ourselves a starting target of £10,000 - Please help us by donating to this cause. All monies donated at the funeral have already been put towards this cause. Thank you

Axxess28 is supporting RNLI Lifeboats that protect hundreds of communities through their 24-hour search and rescue service.

Our Crews rely on the safest, most reliable lifeboats and modern stations to launch from. From the stunning Dorset, Sussex and Kent coastlines to the unpredictable tidal Thames, our favourite places in the South east are enjoyed by millions of people from across the country every year. But the water remains an unpredictable environment that can catch people out. People will always need our help and we will always be there to answer that call.

The RNLI relies on donations from you the public to continue saving lives at sea and on the Thames. Your donation will help keep us afloat in 2021 and support saving lives for years to come.

Thank you for your support.

story:
RNLI lifeboats in Scotland protect hundreds of communities with a 24-hour search and rescue service. Our volunteer crews rely on the safest, most reliable lifeboats and modern stations to launch from. 
Scotlands unrivalled coasts and waters are valued by local communities and visitors alike, with millions travelling to enjoy them, and work on them each year. Keeping a modern fleet of lifeboats maintained, fuelled and ever ready to go to the rescue from all 46 of the lifeboat stations in Scotland is expensive and we rely entirely on voluntary donations to ensure this service is maintained. It costs an average of £155k to run a lifeboat station in Scotland but with the implications of Covid-19, we havent been able to fundraise as normal to help keep our lifeboats afloat. Can you help?

story:
Looking for an easy way to feel good about yourself AND help save the planet at the same time?! Look no further... 

I'm running the Edinburgh Half Marathon in aid of WWF. It'll be the first time I run the 13.1 miles, or 21km, so I'm hoping years of inhaling pasta can help me run fasta (sorry).

Why WWF? The charity is at the forefront of tackling the climate crisis, one of the biggest issues impacting all of us. One in six species is at risk of extinction if we do not act now. I've been a member of WWF for a couple years and receive regular updates on how my donations contribute to a plethora of wildlife conservation activities around the world. WWF really do make a difference. 

On top of the membership donation I have also adopted two of the most endangered species in the world - an Amur Leopard and a mountain gorilla called Ihoho. I-ho-ho-hope (last one, I promise) you share this passion with me and can help me smash my relatively modest fundraising target of £350.

Super grateful for any donations and if you're around Edinburgh on the day of the event, I look forward to thanking you with some post-event pints and pizza (yes, this is a bribe).

Keep safe!

G

We're so often told our planet is at a tipping point, and we need to do a lot more to safeguard our home. By donating as much or as little as you can, you're helping preserve our blue planet for humanity and wildlife.

If that's not enough, you get to watch me go through extreme pain and terrible weather for the next few months! What more could you ask for?

story:
I've joined up with the 'Around the World in 79 Days' team to contribute my miles covered to their team target of travelling (virtually) around the world whilst connecting with countries who are worse affected than the UK by the coronavirus.

By helping ourselves, we will be helping others.  (In aid of UNICEF UK)

One day at a time,
One step at a time,
One vaccine at a time.

To do our part, 79Days has aligned with Unicef’s International Covid-response to prioritise the protection of health workers and the most vulnerable people across the globe. By supporting Unicef in this way, we will contribute to their goal of delivering 2 billion Covid-19 vaccines, 500 million tests and treatment – thus helping to open the door to a brighter future.

From buying and transporting supplies through to administering the vaccine, our efforts will help to deliver history. Our fundraising will help to ensure that:

- vaccines get to even the most remote places in the world.
- vaccines are safely stored using cold chain equipment.
- health workers are protected and trained to vaccinate their communities.

£31 = could provide a full kit to protect a health worker, including boots, gloves, masks and coveralls.

£45 = could provide cold chain equipment to safely store 500 doses of vaccines.

£63 = could transport 4205 doses of vaccines

story:
We're a team of Barclays Operational Risk colleagues who are undertaking an exercise challenge to raise money for Unicef! 

Team members: Andy Cunningham, Gerry Healy, Cameron Hart, Sarah Smalley, Ben Turner, Chris Powell, Monica Lande, Santosh Sharma, David Dobson, Ayo Afolabi-Ajayi, Ainsley Fyfe, Karen Keachie, and Dan McBride. 

Barclays Bank has pledged £100 million to be given through a matched fundraising initiative, support charities directly assisting communities impacted by the pandemic. We have decided to undertake this challenge to do our bit for the wider community, and help make a difference in the fight against Covid-19, with the bank helping to boost the impact of our efforts! 

With this in mind, we though it best to support a charity that is having a significant global impact in the fight against the virus. Unicef operates in virtually every country in the world, and strives to reach every child in need.

Recently Unicef has collaborated with other partners to form the 'COVAX' facility. This project has become the largest vaccine procurement and supply operation in history, and aims to accelerate the manufacture of vaccines and ensure they reach the poorest countries in the world. Unicef are bring their expertise in social mobilization and their global network to ensure they have experts in freight, logistics and storage helping to drive the successful application of this project, and ensuring the greatest possible impact for any money donated.
